author.name: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology

entry.title: Corina E. Tarnita

author.name: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology

entry.content:
Corina Tarnita

Corina E. Tarnita

Bio

Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology Princeton University

With a BA and PhD in Mathematics from Harvard, Corina works on how population structure affects the outcome of evolutionary processes, whether individuals interact at random, or whether they interact in well-defined networks, and how crucial are these in the understanding of biological interactions. Her work led to a general result that describes the effect of structure on evolution.

Title

Abstract

Corina E. Tarnita was originally published by Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology at Spatial Human Cooperation on May 26, 2014.

entry.title: György Szabó

author.name: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology

entry.content:
György Szabó

Bio

Complex System Group Research Institute for Technical Physics and Materials Science Hungarian Academy of Sciences

With an extensive physics background ranging from self-organization in complex systems, driven lattice gases, cellular automata, equilibrium and non-equilibrium statistical physics, Györy works on evolutionary games on graphs and with a focus on maintenance of cooperation

Title

Abstract

György Szabó was originally published by Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology at Spatial Human Cooperation on May 26, 2014.

entry.title: Dirk Semman

author.name: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology

entry.content:
Dirk Semman

Bio

Courant Research Center Evolution of Social Behavior Research Group Evolution of cooperation and prosocial behaviour University of Göttingen

As an evolutionary biologist working experimentally on the topic of human social behavior, Dirk focuses on the evolution and maintenance of cooperative behavior in humans in structured populations, and also on comparative studies on cooperation between humans and between non-human primates.

Title

Abstract

Dirk Semman was originally published by Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology at Spatial Human Cooperation on May 26, 2014.

entry.title: Francisco Santos

author.name: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology

entry.content:
Francisco Santos

Bio

Department of Computer Science and Engineering Instituto Superior Técnico (IST) The engineering school of the University of Lisbon

With research interests spanning several aspects of complex systems, Francisco works on cultural evolution and dynamics of human cooperation with a link to networks science.

Title

Abstract

Francisco Santos was originally published by Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology at Spatial Human Cooperation on May 26, 2014.

entry.title: Angel (Anxo) Sánchez

author.name: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology

entry.content:
Angel (Anxo) Sánchez

Bio

Department of Mathematics Universidad Carlos III de Madrid

Building on his background in physics and mathematics, Anxo has worked on modelling a number of problems arising in different fields, from materials science to biology through behavioral economics.

Title

Abstract

Angel (Anxo) Sánchez was originally published by Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology at Spatial Human Cooperation on May 26, 2014.

entry.title: Matjaž Perc

author.name: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology

entry.content:
Matjaž Perc

Bio

Faculty of Natural Sciences and Mathematics University of Maribor, Slovenia

With a physics background, Matjaž studies noise-induced pattern formation in spatially extended systems with applications to the nervous system, game-theoretical models, and social complexity.

Title

Abstract

Matjaž Perc was originally published by Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology at Spatial Human Cooperation on May 26, 2014.

entry.title: Jorge Pacheco

author.name: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology

entry.content:
Jorge Pacheco

Bio

Departamento de Matemática e Aplicações Universidade do Minho and ATP-Group, CMAF & CBMA, Instituto para a Investigação Interdisciplinar, Lisbon

Active in a variety of research topics, ranging from many-body physics to mathematical description of evolutionary processes such as human cancer, Jorge theoretically explores the evolution of cooperation on complex networks.

Title

Abstract

Jorge Pacheco was originally published by Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology at Spatial Human Cooperation on May 26, 2014.

entry.title: Yamir Moreno

author.name: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology

entry.content:
Yamir Moreno

Bio

Institute for Biocomputation and Physics of Complex Systems Department of Theoretical Physics, Faculty of Sciences University of Zaragoza

With a background in statistical physics and in the physics of complex systems, Yamir has worked on complex networks in several fields of science, including interactions between structure and function in biological, technological and social networks, nonlinear dynamical systems coupled to complex structures and the emergence of collective behavior.

Title

Abstract

Yamir Moreno was originally published by Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology at Spatial Human Cooperation on May 26, 2014.

entry.title: Christoph Hauert

author.name: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology

entry.content:
Christoph Hauert

Bio

Department of Mathematics The University of British Columbia

With a primary interest in the evolution of cooperation and the role of population structures, Christoph works on different aspects of how cooperation arises and is maintained. In particular, this includes voluntary participation, adding reward or punishment opportunities and structured populations.

Title

Abstract

Christoph Hauert was originally published by Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology at Spatial Human Cooperation on May 26, 2014.

entry.title: Jelena Grujic

author.name: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology

entry.content:
Jelena Grujic

Bio

Complexity & Networks Imperial College London

In combination with analytical work, Jelena works on understanding the interaction between spatial structure and cooperative behavior in human societies.

Title

Abstract

Jelena Grujic was originally published by Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology at Spatial Human Cooperation on May 26, 2014.

entry.title: Aljaž Ule

author.name: Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology

entry.content:
Aljaž Ule

Bio

Faculty of Economics and Econometrics of the University of Amsterdam

Assistant professor at the Department of General Economics, Aljaž is focused mainly on dynamics of social institutions such as social networks, culture and social norms, and their effect on social behavior such as voluntary assistance and cooperation, utilising laboratory experiments, computer simulations and game theoretic analysis.

Title

Abstract

Aljaž Ule was originally published by Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Biology at Spatial Human Cooperation on May 26, 2014.
